target_title: Allow switching between all the input sources on the system

note.body:
Just for the record, I was also looking for a solution **on a system that only really needs one keyboard layout** to apply to everyone in GDM (much like a single-user system). [The Arch Linux wiki has some information on this](https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/GDM#Keyboard_layout) but I couldn't get this to work at first, but it finally did end up working by modifying `/etc/vconsole.conf` to contain something like:

```
# This was already present and did not do anything for GDM wayland.
KEYMAP=colemak

# Adding these made colemak (US) apply in GDM instead of regular qwerty after a reboot.
XKBLAYOUT=us
XKBVARIANT=colemak
```

These can be set through `localectl` (as per the linked Arch Linux page), but **the confusing part to me was that X11 configuration still appears to be used when running in Wayland-only mode**.

Hope this helps someone as a workaround in the meantime.

target_title: schema: Add `banner-message-path` setting

note.body:
You mean like
```diff
diff --git a/data/org.gnome.login-screen.gschema.xml b/data/org.gnome.login-screen.gschema.xml
index 2d419a750..08bb1c5f6 100644
--- a/data/org.gnome.login-screen.gschema.xml
+++ b/data/org.gnome.login-screen.gschema.xml
@@ -1,5 +1,10 @@
 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <schemalist gettext-domain="gdm">
+  <enum id="org.gnome.login-screen.BannerSource">
+    <value="1" nick="settings"/>
+    <value="2" nick="file"/>
+  </enum>
+
   <schema id="org.gnome.login-screen" path="/org/gnome/login-screen/">
     <key name="enable-fingerprint-authentication" type="b">
       <default>true</default>
@@ -70,6 +75,15 @@
         Set to true to show the banner message text.
       </description>
     </key>
+    <key name="banner-message-source" enum="org.gnome.login-screen.BannerSource">
+      <default>"settings"</default>
+      <summary>
+        Banner message source
+      </summary>
+      <description>
+        The source of the text banner message on the login screen.
+      </description>
+    </key>
     <key name="banner-message-text" type="s">
       <default>''</default>
       <summary>
```

target_title: monitors.xml not working in GDM when running under Wayland

note.body:
You could check if your `monitors.xml` makes use of experimental features. In my case, copying the file had no effect until I removed the line `<ratemode>variable</ratemode>`. It seems like the `monitors.xml` is ignored as long as it uses experimental features not enabled for `gdm` user. 

To check my assumption, I just set `experimental-features=['variable-refresh-rate']` for `gdm` user and added back `<ratemode>variable</ratemode>` to `monitors.xml`. It works.

<details><summary>If someone wants to try it, here is how to set dconf values for the gdm user:</summary>

```bash
sudo -- sudo -u gdm dbus-launch dconf load / < <(cat <<-EOF

[org/gnome/desktop/peripherals/mouse]
accel-profile='flat'

[org/gnome/desktop/peripherals/touchpad]
tap-to-click=true

[org/gnome/desktop/interface]
cursor-size=24
cursor-theme='Breeze_Light'
font-name='Lato 11'
icon-theme='Papirus-Dark'
text-scaling-factor=1.25

[org/gnome/mutter]
experimental-features=['variable-refresh-rate']

EOF
)
```

Adjust your settings according to your needs. `dconf dump /` shows your current user's settings.
</details>

XAUTHORITY not configured for Xwayland

note.body: gdm doesn't start Xwayland the display server does (so mutter in the case of gnome). the thing that starts Xwayland needs to push XAUTHORITY into the environment if it needs to be set

target_title: XAUTHORITY not configured for Xwayland

note.body: So this is interesting... these days when I log into a gnome desktop, xauthority IS correctly set up and running root applications works fine.  However, this is not the case when I log into a Sway desktop.  So it seems that while the man page for gdm3 still claims that it does this, it has been moved somewhere else, likely gnome-session or something, that is applied for a gnome desktop, but not a Sway one.

GNOME doesn't detect display if turned off and on.
GNOME doesn't detect display if turned off and on.

note.body:
Any updates on this issue? It still exists after about 11 months. Mesa drivers on arch linux. 

GDM version: 47.0

mutter version: 47.1

Gnome version: 47

The issue basically is that the laptop has two GPUs, Radeon graphics (Renoir) and 6800m (NAVI22). An external monitor is connected to 6800m by display port (through USB-C) without any mux switches. If the monitor turns off (due to power outage, etc), when the monitor comes back it is not detected by Gnome / GDM / mutter.

note.body:
It was the On-Screen Keyboard which caused GDM to crash, just like in here: https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=299526 . I believe it is still a bug. Disabling the on-screen keyboard for GDM allows GDM to launch fine. Relevant part of GDM Debug logs: 
```
Oct 05 12:19:57 shivanandvp-jackfruit gnome-shell[1473]: JS ERROR: Gio.IOErrorEnum: TypeError: this._currentSource is null
                                                         
                                                         Stack trace:
                                                           getCurrentGroup@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:2033:13
                                                           _updateKeys@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1658:48
                                                           _setupKeyboard@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1302:14
                                                           _init@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1230:14
                                                           Keyboard@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1179:4
                                                           _syncEnabled@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1111:30
                                                           KeyboardManager@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/keyboard.js:1091:14
                                                           _initializeUI@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/main.js:240:16
                                                           start@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/main.js:173:11
                                                           @resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/init.js:12:47
                                                           @resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/init.js:21:20
                                                           
                                                         @resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/init.js:21:20
Oct 05 12:19:57 shivanandvp-jackfruit gnome-shell[1473]: Execution of main.js threw exception: Module resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/init.js threw an exception
```
